reviewText:
Would I recommend Half-Life? Hell yes. Would I recommend Half-Life: Source? Er, maybe. The original Half-Life was, and still is, an absolutely fantastic game. The story and how it’s conveyed to the player works extremely well, and the controls, gameplay mechanics, visuals, and sound are all phenomenal. Very few bugs, and certainly none game-breakingly noteworthy.

However, this is where Half-Life: Source fails. This game’s major problem is its glitches and bugs. Some minor, some absolutely game-breaking. On one hand, you have scientist’s AI screwed up, running into open fire, constantly shooting off their response lines. On the other hand, you have some parts of the game where the textures and models go ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, essentially simulating your graphics card melting.

Even with the bugs, the game does try to make it up with some enhancements thanks to the Source engine. The water effects are slightly better (although in my experiences it’s just extraordinarily shiny and reflective), and the lighting effects are significantly improved, although inconsistent when walking into an area that needs to load. However, the HL2 bullet hole decals make it possible to create magnificent works of art with your crowbar on walls.

Thankfully, the gameplay, controls, and overall look and appeal of the game is still there, unaltered. There’s no denying that the game is awesome. Half-Life in general is awesome. I just love how people on the GoldSrc version of Half-Life were complaining about the game having extremely old and outdated graphics, saying HL:Source is better in this field. Well, it’s not. A majority of textures and models are completely identical. Aside from the water and bullet decals, the games are visually the same, which is something I’m completely fine with. The regular version of Half-Life actually comes with the HD texture pack, something this port lacks. It essentially gives the game updated models to characters and weapons, and slightly enhanced textures in some areas. It’s nice, but not essential, which is fine.

Overall, yeah, go ahead and get it. If this is ever on sale for cheaper than the regular Half-Life, and you own neither, by all means, go ahead and get it. You (hopefully) won’t regret it.

reviewText: First, let's get the formalities out of the way. Half-Life is Half-Life. It's unimaginably fantastic. Half-Life Source is different though. It's essentially the same game, just on a more updated engine. And while that might sound like a good thing, Half-Life 1 wasn't designed for the Source engine. It doesn't fit. The updated textures look strange and out of place, it's buggy as all hell, and the AI is changed. That last one's big. Considering there's no cutscenes in Half-Life, any important scenes are done as scripted events. And with the AI different, they just don't act the way they're intended, making you miss important story points. I've also noticed that they move around a lot, so you'll get swarmed real quick, which makes the game go from challenging to unfair. It also doesn't help that weapon switching is unnecessarily slow in this one compared to the original, giving a horde of enemies barrel-assing around the corner ample time to punch holes in you. Also, with the new Source engine, any music that's playing is cut off when you move to the next map, and since there's music cues right before a map change, you'll hear the first five seconds of the song before it just stops playing. Seriously, if you want it, make sure you play the original first. I may have under twenty hours on the Source version, but I have over 130 hours on the GoldSrc version. And that's the campaign alone. Don't be stupid. Get the original.

reviewText:
Half-Life is an amazing adventure, sci-fi, and FPS game from Valve.  Your goal is to escape the ruined Black Mesa (the same one that is rivaled with Aperture Science from Portal) while fighting the invading aliens.  Even though first person shooters are generally hated today becayse they are considered rehashes and uncreative, this game is the exact opposite.
You start off in a train ride on your way to some sort of test chamber everyone is talking about.  As you take the ride, you will see a lot of different places that you will visit later, so pay attention.  You eventually make your way to the test chamber when disaster strikes and aliens invade.  It sounds a bit cliche at first, but the game tells the story in such a great way that it works.  You eventually meet a security guard and encounter enemies.  The security guard then helps you, which brings me to my first point.
One amazing thing about Half-Life is that it gives choices.  When you meet the security guard,  you already have your first weapon: a crowbar.  Since a crowbar is a weapon, and there is a person with a gun in front of you, and you need to survive... well, you can see what most people would do.  About 20 minutes into the game, you can already get a gun early, or you can have the security guard help you, until he is apparently can't crawl through a whole that an average scientist can... what a security guard.  This is just one example, and there are a lot of security guards willing to help you.
Anyway, onto the graphics.  They're not as good as other Source games, but don't let that discourage you.  Games are meant to be played, not looked at.  Also, if you want to, you can make the game look like the original Half-Life.
I would reccomend Half-Life to pretty much everbody, as long as you don't get scared easily.  Trust me, you will get a bit scared.  There is a creepy atmosphere, zombies, and A LOT of tension and a feeling you are being watched.  There are no jumpscares are other cheap scares, luckily (I'm looking at you, Slender).
This game gets a 10/10

reviewText:
The attention to detail in Valve’s games has never been amiss and I’ve always been impressed by how much they put into this series. The setting for the game is an underground research facility, your character witnesses a catastrophe that plunges the facility into chaos. You have to fend off alien species to escape the facility and try to figure out what is happening. It’s a sci-fi game and that’s what gives it its character. The weapons especially get more interesting as the game develops, as you start to discover more and more alien technology.

I used to love watching my dad play this as a kid, but I just never managed to be able to get very far myself until I decided to go back to it now. The Half-Life 1 series is extremely nostalgic to me and its great still being able to play these games despite how old they are. For me, they are great, but I imagine for people that have never played them before, they might just look awful.
Despite that, I would hope the overall feel and story of the game would be compelling enough to make those people enjoy it anyway.

Half-Life: Source has a few bugs here and there, a few of which I thought were going to be game breaking for me. But there was always a way around it. The glitches and bugs were tedious but given how old the game is it’s forgivable.

The source engine reboot of this game changes up the game quite a bit. It was given new map textures, new weapon models, new NPC models and enhances to the sound. The changes are good, they definitely make the game look better. But I enjoy the original just as much, if not more. I’m used to and remember the old one. Which oddly, when I played this game I’m not too sure what happened with it. I downloaded the game, fired it up and played quite a bit in one session. Not noticing that it was all actually the old game assets. I shut it down and gave the game a break and when I booted it back up suddenly the new stuff was being used. Weird!

Anyway, there is never a dull moment in this game, there is action and something new always around the corner. It’s essentially a first person shooter, but it manages to break it up in-between and give you enough else to do so that it doesn’t get boring.

It’s all around a fun game and I think you should give it a try, even if you haven’t got that Half-Life nostalgia that I do.


TL;DR : Old but great, lot of nostalgia for me. It’s a good first person shooter sci-fi game, give it a try.

reviewText:
For my review of Half-Life, check out my review of the original game. This is just a short insight on my thoughts of the Source version.

Half-Life: Source is simply the original Half-Life ported to Valve's newer (at the time) Source engine, it doesn't bring anything new to the table aside from a few new menu options such as selecting a chapter, but it does improve a handful of aspects, mostly minor and technical. The most noteable changes are to the water, the ragdoll physics and the map lighting (in some cases).

There are plenty of other minor things that you will notice after playing through once, it's like a new layer of polish, but nothing that would make me recommend buying this version over the original game as unfortunately the Source port has also caused a large number of bugs and errors to arise that were never in the original version. While some of the new features and mechanics in the Source engine are nice, the game hasn't really been updated to take those aspects into account, and thus, more problems popped up.

So I have mixed feelings about Half-Life: Source, but I'd say that this version is worth playing through at least once if you are a Half-Life fan, it has a slightly different feel to it but ultimately I'd say to just stick to the original version of the game instead. It may be dated but that's what gives it it's charm.

reviewText:
Half-Life Source is a great idea on paper. A complete remake of the original Half-Life but in the Source engine with all the technological and graphical improvements that would bring. It is something a lot of us fans of the original would love to see. Unfortunately that is simply not what happened here.

Half-Life Source only barely qualifies as being a port. They didn't change or upgrade anything, everything looks and feels the same and the only way you can tell it's a Source game is by looking at the game name.

Graphics, animations, physics. Nothing has been improved to what Source is capable of. It is Half-Life running in Source sure, but if you can't tell the difference does it really matter?

It is a great disappointment and a huge waste of money. If I had lost my copy of Half-Life back in the day I would have gladly shelled out the cash for a new copy so I could keep playing. But this isn't back in the day and this isn't the right Half-Life. You don't get the mods with this one.

Stay away from this horribly rushed money grab. It's a waste of your time and your money. Go buy the original Half-Life instead or if you already own that, go play the Black Mesa mod. It's free and it doesn't suck.

reviewText:
Half-Life: Prettier Twin Sister

Pros: Classic, Dialogue, Gameplay, Graphics
Cons: Platforming

Originally released in 1998, Half-Life revolutionized the FPS genre, winning award after award.  The narrative within evolved as allies and enemies would spout little tidbits about the calm, quiet protagonist.  Gritty and realistic, gameplay involved a myriad of enemies and traps.  Although a completely linear game, the setting varied from huge desert cliffs to claustrophobic air vents.

At the time, most games heavily involved platforming and Half-Life was no exception.  Small annoyances can still be found, for example, trying to move along some ladders.  Younger crowds might find the graphics outdated and clunky.  But these faults are fairly insignificant for a game published more than a decade ago.

A classic, revolutionary title that all FPS fans, serious gamers, and appreciative players should own.

10/10

reviewText: Half-Life is one of the best and most influential fps games of the last few decades, and I think most would agree. Half-Life: Source is an update using Valve's source engine. While it's mostly the same, from level design, weapons, ect. there are minor differences such as updated water, better lighting and ragdolls. But this version has a lot more bugs than it's Goldsrc counterpart. Some that i came across were a floating scientist in the Anomalous Materials chapter, invisible barnacle tongues and the tentacle in Blast Pit not doing any damage (although that might not be a bug as I've heard that it was severely nerfed and can barely hit you). As for which version you should get for a first time player, it's kind of a toss-up. On one hand, Source looks slightly better, can be played in widescreen and has the updated water/lighting, but the original has much less bugs and has many more mods. It's really just up to you which you want. If you already have the original, though, there's not enough of anything new to justify a purchase. If you want a true source remake from the ground up, then buy BlackMesa.

reviewText:
Half Life is a classic game, enjoyed by many in it's time, and even now. This however, is not exactly the original game, but more of a remake, built in the Source engine. In my review of the game I'm going to sum the whole game up, with an honest review on it's ups and downs - so let's get right into it.

So let's start of with the storyline of the game. You stard of as a newly graduated Gordon Freeman on his way to work at the Black Mesa research facility. When you get to work, you have to get into a test chamber, where they are putting some kind of crystal onto a laser, but something goes wrong. The crystal messes with time and space and opens a portal to another dimension called Xen, through this portal, alien beings wreck havock in the facility. In the mean time the government here's of this, and decides not to help, but to kill everyone and everything involved.

Nowadays, this story seems pretty generic, and is used in practically every sci-fi movie ever made, but this was made in 1998. Even still, I do think it was a bit lazy, but was a fun and exciting story nevertheless.

The game includes many strategy based puzzles, and most things were very challenging, and some points I had to watch a YouTube tutorial on how on earth to complete parts. These puzzles were slightly annoying though at times, such as when the tram in 'On a Rail' and the conveyorbelts in 'Residue Processing'. Despite this, you always feel a sence of achievement after completing them, which is great.

The original Half Life was a game that was made in 1998, and the graphics, while not horrible, are not great. This Source remake version was made in 2004, and the graphics are slightly improved, but I don't really think it matters which game you decide to play. I do think that the Source version however, was not ported over very well, as there were many scripted events that were broken, such as a security guard dying and so on. Also on the chapter, 'Residue Processing' which jumping from platform to platform, the screen will randomly show yellow, red and black splatters of colour across the screen, (see screenshot on my profile) which made the level almost impossible.

Overall, I found this a great game to play, it was verey enjoyable, but extremely annoying and painful in certain chapters. I am going to give it a 7/10, purely because there was a lot of stuff that was broken, but aside from that I would reccomend you play it.

Everything else from gibs to med packs uses the old HL1 physics where it simply falls or for gibs bounces and bounces. The water looks nice but does not fit in when everything around it looks cartoony. It ruins the dam scene for me atleast. reviewText:
Half-Life Source is a slightly enhanced version of the 1998 classic.

This supposed remake retains most of the original game's textures, models and animation but favours towards the better world effects available from the new Source engine of the time. Half-Life Source has a Havoc powered physics engine with enemies and objects obeying Newton's three laws, picture-quality water reflections and expanded scenary - now built as geometry rather than painted on backdrops. Also, the sound and presenetation now borrows heavily from Half-Life 2.

My opinion of Half-Life Source is rather mixed, befuddled even. HL: Source feels very sloppily put together and thrown over. Valve could of and should of done a complete overhaul of the game. It's lukewarm reception from the many alienated players of the game led to the creation of Black Mesa Source, a total conversion set to unofficially reimagine the first game on the source engine. I implore you to wait for it instead. Otherwise, buy the original.

reviewText:
To make that people understand: Half-Life: Source is Half-Life. I enjoyed it because of that. Everything related to the original game is there, so, yeah, Half-Life: Source is a very good game in that aspect. Read that review to understand that HL:S could be a good choice for those that never played Half-Life - http://steamcommunity.com/id/vicrabb/recommended/70. For people like me, that played the original back then and many times after, the only real change seen is in the graphics but not in a spectacular way.

Contrary to the title, the Source Engine, from Half-Life 2, isn't used at all. In reality, I feel like it's just the HD Texture Pack that was applied. And that pack was used for Half-Life: Blueshift, released in 2001. The mod-that-became-a-game Black Mesa is better if you want a real Half-Life with the Source Engine (though it's not sticking strictly to the original in terms of level design).

I felt cheated. I don't remember if I bought the game or if I got it in a collector's edition of Half-Life 2 but I felt cheated there. I was expecting much better thing from Half-Life: Source and in the end, apart the fun that is still intact because it's Half-Life, I felt that the promise wasn't there.

That's why I'm thumbing down this version of the game for people that love Half-Life and that would have preferred a better treatment for it. It doesn't mean that the game is bad in itself, I repeat, it's Half-Life. But I prefer to buy the original than that, that's all.

reviewText:
This is one of the best games I have ever played. Half-Life is a classic that should be played by anyone who appreciates FPS's. In fact, it's your obligation to play this game, because it was the first to do so many things in video games. There are many games that have heavily leaned on the format, gameplay and story telling strategies of this game. The game is very dated, and it shows, but Valve did implement the Source engine which gives it a more polished, free-flowing look. I was able to disregard the dated graphics, because I knew that this was such an original and classic game.

The first half hour of the game is brilliant, because nothing is really happening, but there is an ere tone and feeling that lets you know that something's not right. Some subtle foreshadowing occurs when some of the computers break, and a scientist says the power is going to be switched on to 105%. It's show-not-tell things like this that make the game so gripping and immersive. It's something we don't seem to see in many games anymore.

Anyway, during the first three quarters of the game, you're running around, collecting new weapons, killing aliens, and soldiers sent there to kill you, (a perfectly executed plot twist) solving puzzles, picking up more of the story, riding on rails, launching rockets, blowing up helicopters, storming military bases, navigating mine fields, annihilating green, bangy, tentacle thingies, electrocuting, and blowing up giant, blue flamethrower monsters; the list can go on and on. Basically, you're just having a lot of fun. The constant change of objectives really keeps the player immersed in the game. You never feel like you're repeating the same things over and over again. This is a staple in the Half-Life franchise. Once you start getting bored of something, it changes it up so that you're doing something different and more exciting. The pacing in this game is also phenomenal. It usually goes in the order of: Action event, slow puzzle event, action event slow puzzle event, with some events that feature action and puzzle at the same time, and story exposition sprinkled around and mixed in through everything you do. It's constant fun that never frustrates you or makes you feel cheated.

The subtle rise in difficulty is more subtle than, you know, just changing the color of the monster. It's realistic, and makes you feel the tension rising around the Black Mesa facility. The first three quarters of the game are nearly flawless.

In my opinion, the only downside to this game is the last quarter where you play in the alien world, Xen. This segment of the game really breaks up the immersion. The gravity is toned down, so everything you've gotten used to in the first part of the game is scrapped for a floaty, hard to manoeuvre, way of moving. It's also very slow. From a story telling perspective, it's mind blowing, but from a gameplay perspective, it's quite dull and frustrating. During the chapter Xen, you're just platforming, trying to figure out where to go. Gonarch's Lair was just an annoying, frustrating, slow paced boss fight, But the REAL kicker was interloper.

I hated this level. It was way too long, way too difficult, way to confusing, and way too frustrating. If there was an enemy I could have removed from this game it would be those flying baby thingies, but they were everywhere here and they would respawn all the time! There's never enough health, energy, or ammo for you, so you have too eek by in this extremely hard level. In most levels, if it was hard, it was because you needed to change your strategy. It was your fault if you died. But in this level, there are just way too many overpowered enemies. You're trying to save your health and running out of ammo, and BOOM! You're hit with ten million, flying babies, and bee shooting giants, while being hit with vortigaunt lightning from every corner. The only way to get through this level is to set the difficulty to easy, and die a million times before you memorise where each enemy will be and when he will attack. That's no fun. That's just drudgery.

Nihilanth was just a giant version of those annoying flying babies. Great. To be honest, he was just mediocre. Okay, I do hate how all the Zelda bosses, for example, have huge shiny targets on them that show you exactly where to place a bomb or shoot an arrow, but at least they help you figure out how to defeat it. In Nihilanth, I had no idea how to defeat the monster. shooting it did nothing, and it kept sending me away to these weird caves by throwing portals at me. I was completely lost. I had to go on youtube and see how it was done before I even knew how to kill it. It was still too hard too kill it though. If you play it the way it was intended and jump up onto those cliff things, it's really hard, and he will keep sending portals at you. If you're cheap like me and just hid behind the spiky rocks, then it's easier, but it's painfully repeditive and tedious.

Boss fights in this game were not good with the exception of the green tentacle thing. I will cut it some slack though, because it was kind of a 90's thing to have bosses in your games, and this was a very hard game to put bosses into.

In the last chapter, you're given a monologue from the mysterious G-man, who you may have noticed stalking you throughout the game. He makes you go through a portal, and then the credits hit, reminding you how good the soundtrack in this game was.

All in all, Half-Life was a classic, and should be played by anyone who likes video games. If you like steam you should play this game to show your respects to Valve. It was the first game they made. Half-Life rose to my personal favorite video game franchise after the Metroid Franchise was ruined by Other M. Anyway, just play this game. You have no excuse not to. Oh, and Gabe, PUHLEEEZZZE MAKE HALF-LIFE THREEEEE!

reviewText:
The crappy port of the former greatest PC game of all time. This is Half-Life with a ton of additional bugs,better water, ragdolls, improved(?) skyboxes, motion blur, bloom and nothing else. Not good! And whaddya know the port was done by Gearbox. Some of the alterations to the gunplay already affect it negatively but what's most shocking is how buggy it is and how many lenghty loading zones that weren't present in the original Half-Life have been added. One level is even uglier than it was in the original shockingly by making the map look far less expansive:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=696250055
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=696250301&fileuploadsuccess=1
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=696253620
(The last picture is from Black Mesa's faithful remake.)
If you've ever seen a picture of a scientist floating above a chair then the picture was in fact taken from Half-Life: Source as that bug never happend in Half-Life 1. Oh and here's an example of one of the many bugs ingame:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=696258149
Note the lack of sky and the fact that my HEV suit has dissapeared. There are also instances where new Half-Life 2 textures are right alongside badly ported Half-Life 1 textures leading to a George Lucas remastered effect. Not to mention some broken scripting, missing music and textures shining as bright as the sun in dark rooms. The orginal runs flawlessly and works in widescreen and in terms of gameplay still holds up quite well with the obvious (Doesn't bother me.) exception being the graphics which are more than a little dated. Oh but of course you could always just toggle to use the HD models instead. If you wan't a version of Half-Life with subtle improvements to atmosphere, immersion and better graphics and that actually take full advantage of the Source engine get Black Mesa instead. In fact both the Black Mesa mod (Black Mesa retail/Steam edition runs on Source 2013 and recently so did Half-Life:Source.) and Half-Life: Source run on Source 2007. Half-Life: Source was so crummy that we have it to thank for inspiring people remake Half-Life on the Source engine themselves. If Counter Strike: Source was just 1.6 visuals with the Source engine as a backend and a plethora of bugs and weird changes to the gameplay you would have pretty disapointed wouldn't you? This doesn't do much of note visually and adds longer loading to really hammer the nail in the coffin. This is pretty useless and I don't reccomend getting it in the year 2016.

reviewText: Has NOT aged well... I really can't stand it. Yes, this game is important to history, so you should at least try it at some point, but I don't think it's worth anything anymore. At this point, it's a relic that represents a landmark in gaming history more than it is a game. My main gripes are its absolute adherence to old-school shooter design with the modern (as we know it) narrative design layered over it. It was revolutionary at the time, but so many games have come along and done what it did so much better that it's impossible to look back on this and still say it's good on it's own terms. Maybe Black Mesa will change my opinion on it (especially if they put in PROPER full controller support), but until then? reviewText:
I finally got around to playing the original Half-Life, wanting to expand my knowledge on the universe that Valve had created.

This is possibly the worst Valve game I have yet played. It has aged poorly. I guess if I had the fortune of playing it upon release I would appreciate it more, but I just can't understand how it managed to garner so much praise back in 1998. Perhaps there were some major changes that affected gameplay when they released the Source version in 2005?

The AI is completely broken. You can edge around corners and slowly pick off immobile enemies by shooting their feet. If they can't see you their AI won't kick in. Pretty terrible mechanics. Apparently the AI was taken from Half-Life 2 when HL: Source was released. It doesn't show it.

The controls are way too twitchy. It's almost impossible to succesfully climb down a ladder without dying the first time. You often go sliding off edges as if Gordon's feet are made of ice. It was certainly a frustrating experience.

There is also absolutely no story or character development. None. You are Gordon Freeman, a scientist. You open a portal to another dimension. You close the portal. The end. Everyone you meet along the way is disposable and has no distinguishing features or names.

There is no explanation for any of what is happening, there is no lead up to Half-Life 2. The reasons for the military presence are not explained, neither is the fact that they are replaced with Combine forces in the sequel, however many years later.

The only connection between Half-Life and Half-Life 2 is Gordon Freeman and the G-Man. That's it. The only recurring enemies are the headcrabs and Vortigaunt, the latter of which are apparently on your side for some reason. Who knows how they ended up on Earth if the portal was closed.

This was an amazingly empty experience, void of any story or sense of progression. I understand that was Valve's and, especially, Gabe Newell's intentions, but it just doesn't sit right with me.

I know my opinion will go against the grain and, while I did enjoy the game overall and appreciate how it is placed within the Half-Life universe, I still can not overlook the many smaller flaws that become overbearing during gameplay. I have to wonder if these issues exist in the original Half-Life game or if they are exclusive to the Source version.

reviewText:
Is Half-Life truly the greatest game of all time? I can answer that question with one word.

No.

My friend had been pestering me for months to play this game. I had heard so many wonderful things about it, “It’s the greatest game of all time”, “It has an amazing story” are just two of the many great claims I’ve heard about this game. I’ve got to say, I’m extremely disappointed.

After launching the game, I’m greeted by some pretty abysmal graphics. The original game was released sometime around 1996, so poor graphics are to be expected in the original version of the game. What’s not to be expected is for there to be poor graphics in the remake/remaster of the game (Half-Life Source). If the graphics are this bad, I might have well just played the original version.

At first I put this aside; a game with bad graphics doesn’t always equal a bad game. I decided proceed through the “tutorial” area until I actually reach the real part of the game (in which you get your first weapon). I was quite frustrated to find out that I had to use a crowbar as a weapon, which in my opinion is quite a bad design decision. You are going to get a gun later in the game anyway, so why not just provide a gun earlier in the game? Another thing I can't work out is why did they put glasses on the main character? It doesn't seem very badass for the main character to wear glasses.

I then struggle to play though the game due to the dry story and boring combat mechanics. I honestly don’t know why everyone thinks the story to this game is so amazing. A science laboratory gets filled with aliens and you need to escape that laboratory. The story doesn’t get any more complicated or in-depth than that.

You also see a man in a suit from time to time. I don’t see the point in this since you never get the chance to fight him. He is clearly the bad guy in the game, but instead of fighting him at the end of the game, you just speak to him instead. What a disappointment.

Take my advice. Save your money and spend it elsewhere.

reviewText:
One of the best FPSs of all time. At some point in your life you must have heard about this game, or it sequel. Every game in the genre borrows some elements from this one, guaranteed.

The arms you with a handful of weapons you mst make your way though a ridiculously big research facility overrun with aliens and military forces. A non stop action package with zero cutscenes.

The story is explained through small chats with the surviving members of the facility and paying attention to enemy  conversations. You can also gather some extra details by cautiously examining the environment.

All the enemy soldiers have an instantly recognizeable scruffy voice while the friendly NPCs sound more calmed and soft, for the most part. This game also has some os the most well known scores for PC games (like the Nuclear Mission jam), and the weapon sounds are very well made.

Although this is a remake of the original release for the source engine the graphics were not enhanced at all, so don't expect brilliant quality. Some users also say this version is inferior to the original because it added extra bugs and other issues, but I encountered none during my playthrough. Your mileage may vary though.

Overall, this game is a classic and a must play for anyone who enjoys videogames.

reviewText:
One of the best FPSs of all time. At some point in your life you must have heard about this game, or it sequel. Every game in the genre borrows some elements from this one, guaranteed.

The arms you with a handful of weapons you mst make your way though a ridiculously big research facility overrun with aliens and military forces. A non stop action package with zero cutscenes.

The story is explained through small chats with the surviving members of the facility and paying attention to enemy  conversations. You can also gather some extra details by cautiously examining the environment.

All the enemy soldiers have an instantly recognizeable scruffy voice while the friendly NPCs sound more calmed and soft, for the most part. This game also has some os the most well known scores for PC games (like the Nuclear Mission jam), and the weapon sounds are very well made.

Although this is a remake of the original release for the source engine the graphics were not enhanced at all, so don't expect brilliant quality. Some users also say this version is inferior to the original because it added extra bugs and other issues, but I encountered none during my playthrough. Your mileage may vary though.

Overall, this game is a classic and a must play for anyone who enjoys videogames.

reviewText:
Half-Life/HLS is a game that is held in high esteem by many as the best FPS, or even computer game, of all time.  While I would say that you have to take all this praise with a grain of salt, I would still consider it a game that you should probably play.

Pros:

Awesome storytelling.  The story is not necessarily the most complex or the best in gaming, but the way it is presented to you is hard to beat.  98% of all information that you need to know can be found in-game; the other 2% are essentially backstory.

Well designed environment.  Half-Life: Source is not necessarily pretty, as it is an engine update of a game released in 1998, but the environments are designed to both a.) give you the feeling of being in Black Mesa, and b.) giving you a direct goal, even if that requires backtracking.

Changing game genre.  This may sound strange, but the game will often change its genre, depending on where you are.  Early in the game, it's just survival-horror as you fight your way through aliens, just trying to escape.  Then it becomes more like a real shooter, with people firing back, as the army arrives and begins to fight you.  The battles gradually grow larger and larger, the intensity level growing... and then it goes back to survival horror.  THEN, the game comes back to more tactical shooting, just in time for the most epic level of the game.  You then travel to the alien homeworld to kill their leader.  All this keeps the game feeling fresh and new.

Great gunplay.  Guns are given to you only when it is necessary, and most weapons have a purpose.  You will, at some point, use all of the weapons.  The gunplay itself is commendable, with a lot of different options against enemies.  Some enemies are tough to take down, but with the right combo they can be killed with ease.

Great Enemy A.I.  Half-Life: Source/Half-Life has better A.I. then I see in games that were released in 2005 and 2007.  The enemy A.I., especially in squads, will work together to bring you down.  The squad A.I. is often tough to beat.

Good soundtrack.  The music is good, but it fades into the background, in a good way, that prevents it from being too overbearing.

Cons:

Labrythine map design.  Especially in the later levels, there will be many a place where you will go one way, then have to go back where you came from, then have to go down an entirely different route.  In some places this is a good, but in others it is just frustrating.  There is a TON of backtracking in this game, making the gameplay feel somewhat tedious.

Extremely poor friendly A.I.  This game, HLS, does a better job of making sure they follow you, but that's just the first step.   Often, friendly A.I.  will run into mines, shoot you if you go ahead of them, get in front of your line of fire, or even run into heavily armed enemies.  The middle two are particularly frustrating, especially in the earlier levels.  There was many a time where I would run in front of my ally, confident in his competency, when I would get shot in the back.  Also, there was one time where I was shooting and he ran in front of me, and I got him in the arm.  Due to his coding that makes him seek revenge, (which is justified) he shot and killed me.  (I had low health.)

As mentioned before, the game can be very tedious.  Length is a good thing, but Half-Life's levels can be annoyingly long.  There have been times where I've wanted to play through the whole thing, but I just had to stop.  It's a sad thing that can often drag the fun of the game down.

I would give this game a 8/10.  It is well designed, with good enemies, weapons, and GENERAL map design, but some more intricate maps, and longer maps, can be very boring, dragging down the game.

reviewText: This game played a key role in the transition to full 3D in first person gaming. After the richness and depth seen at the climax of the '2.5D' era, the move to full 3D seemed to throw all that advancement out the window. Whereas the 2.5D era had reached a point where such depth was near inherent, successors like Quake and Quake 2 showed a simplicity that while enjoyable, left an undeniable lacking. And gone were so many of the innovations defined by the previous era. On consoles, a game named Golden Eye brought many of those past innovations kicking and screaming, into the 3D space; On PC, at the forefront of the charge, rode the mighty Half Life. Granted, despite the game's release, the war remained unwon, but the battle was a major victory, and Half Life will never be forgotten.

reviewText:
If you have not yet played any version of the first Half-Life, I strongly reccommend you play the very first and original version of it, not the Source version.

If you think it's a complete remake and overhaul of the original ala Counter-Strike: Source, then you would be wrong. It's just the original game ported to the Source Engine. The result is alright for a few things, but in all honesty I've found it to be less enjoyable than the original.

On the plus side, the best thing I can say about is that the water looks better. Yeah, it's not much, but you can actually see through it here unlike the original, which can be helpful for getting an idea of underwater areas before diving into them and can allow you to more easily target underwater enemies without actually having to be in the water and risk attacks from them.

There's also the addition of ragdolls, which generally look much nicer than the set death animations and poses NPCs took on in the original whenever they were killed.

However, some enemies don't have the same behavior as in the original, some enemies are less aggressive and will not seem to notice you as often,  It might make the combat a bit easier, but that's what takes away from the gameplay, it's not quite as challenging as the original is.

Other NPCs don't seem to have translated very well over to the port. One of the best examples being the friendly NPCs, Scientists and Security Guards will constantly make pain noises and grunts after being injured just once, something that's rather annoying to listen to if you want any to accompany you for backup.

Overall, the game just doesn't have the same old feel of the original that I found myself enjoying and is also less challenging than it. I definitely don't recommend playing it before the original Half-Life, at the very least. It's not necessarily a bad" remake

reviewText:
I’m going to recommend Half Life: Source to modern gamers but just barely. I never played it nor Half Life 2 back in the day, so I am completely unbiased by nostalgia. Both games have intrigued me for years, though, and I saw them together in a Steam sale bundle so decided to pick them up and finally play through them. The original Half Life looks quite dated and is missing many modern FPS creature comforts we have come to take for granted, but still shines thanks to its brilliant & pioneering design.

Yes, it was state of the art when it came out and a truly groundbreaking game for its time. But is it fun to play now? When I first fired the game up my initial thought was, “I can’t do this. It’s too old.” The polygon models are harsh, even in Source version. People’s hands look sharp enough to poke your eye out. The sound is downright terrible in some places. Environments are often sparse with low-res textures. It can also be difficult to tell whether or not you are damaging certain enemies.

Despite all that, I took a break and came back to it. I’m happy to say I got hooked shortly afterward. Half Life is made so well, I was able to overlook its technical shortcomings and get immersed in Gordon’s flight from Black Mesa. The pace is frenetic, rarely giving you the chance to catch your breath. It’s a very intelligent shooter, also. There are many hidden areas, multiple paths, clever puzzles, and neat surprise moments along the way. You keep moving almost continuously to the very mysterious ending.

Which brings me to why I almost gave the title a thumbs down. The ending is deeply unsatisfying. After everything that happened I still only had the vaguest idea of what was going on. I think there was an accident in the lab that led to an alien invasion, with either the gov’t or privately contracted troops trying to destroy the entire facility to cover it up. And then, dude in suit with briefcase in the interdimensional train car. The end.

I have started Half Life 2 and while I love it so far, in terms of story it adds even more confusion to the narrative. Gordon Freeman is one of the most incurious people in the universe, never once pausing to ask anybody, “Hey, WTF is happening!?!?” I’m hoping more light gets shed on the plot as I progress through the sequel. You can only tease people for so long before they get bored.

From a pure gameplay standpoint, though, Half Life: Source will not disappoint. If you have never played it and can deal with outdated graphics & sound, go ahead & pick it up. If not, you can skip straight to Half Life 2 without missing a whole lot. In other words, you’ll be just as confused at the beginning of HL2 whether you played through the first game or not.

reviewText:
I’m going to recommend Half Life: Source to modern gamers but just barely. I never played it nor Half Life 2 back in the day, so I am completely unbiased by nostalgia. Both games have intrigued me for years, though, and I saw them together in a Steam sale bundle so decided to pick them up and finally play through them. The original Half Life looks quite dated and is missing many modern FPS creature comforts we have come to take for granted, but still shines thanks to its brilliant & pioneering design.

Yes, it was state of the art when it came out and a truly groundbreaking game for its time. But is it fun to play now? When I first fired the game up my initial thought was, “I can’t do this. It’s too old.” The polygon models are harsh, even in Source version. People’s hands look sharp enough to poke your eye out. The sound is downright terrible in some places. Environments are often sparse with low-res textures. It can also be difficult to tell whether or not you are damaging certain enemies.

Despite all that, I took a break and came back to it. I’m happy to say I got hooked shortly afterward. Half Life is made so well, I was able to overlook its technical shortcomings and get immersed in Gordon’s flight from Black Mesa. The pace is frenetic, rarely giving you the chance to catch your breath. It’s a very intelligent shooter, also. There are many hidden areas, multiple paths, clever puzzles, and neat surprise moments along the way. You keep moving almost continuously to the very mysterious ending.

Which brings me to why I almost gave the title a thumbs down. The ending is deeply unsatisfying. After everything that happened I still only had the vaguest idea of what was going on. I think there was an accident in the lab that led to an alien invasion, with either the gov’t or privately contracted troops trying to destroy the entire facility to cover it up. And then, dude in suit with briefcase in the interdimensional train car. The end.

I have started Half Life 2 and while I love it so far, in terms of story it adds even more confusion to the narrative. Gordon Freeman is one of the most incurious people in the universe, never once pausing to ask anybody, “Hey, WTF is happening!?!?” I’m hoping more light gets shed on the plot as I progress through the sequel. You can only tease people for so long before they get bored.

From a pure gameplay standpoint, though, Half Life: Source will not disappoint. If you have never played it and can deal with outdated graphics & sound, go ahead & pick it up. If not, you can skip straight to Half Life 2 without missing a whole lot. In other words, you’ll be just as confused at the beginning of HL2 whether you played through the first game or not.

reviewText:
If you have not yet played any version of the first Half-Life, I strongly reccommend you play the very first and original version of it, not the Source version.

If you think it's a complete remake and overhaul of the original ala Counter-Strike: Source, then you would be wrong. It's just the original game ported to the Source Engine. The result is alright for a few things, but in all honesty I've found it to be less enjoyable than the original.

On the plus side, the best thing I can say about is that the water looks better. Yeah, it's not much, but you can actually see through it here unlike the original, which can be helpful for getting an idea of underwater areas before diving into them and can allow you to more easily target underwater enemies without actually having to be in the water and risk attacks from them.

There's also the addition of ragdolls, which generally look much nicer than the set death animations and poses NPCs took on in the original whenever they were killed.

However, some enemies don't have the same behavior as in the original, some enemies are less aggressive and will not seem to notice you as often,  It might make the combat a bit easier, but that's what takes away from the gameplay, it's not quite as challenging as the original is.

Other NPCs don't seem to have translated very well over to the port. One of the best examples being the friendly NPCs, Scientists and Security Guards will constantly make pain noises and grunts after being injured just once, something that's rather annoying to listen to if you want any to accompany you for backup.

Overall, the game just doesn't have the same old feel of the original that I found myself enjoying and is also less challenging than it. I definitely don't recommend playing it before the original Half-Life, at the very least. It's not necessarily a bad" remake

reviewText:
It's hard to think of a bad Valve title, but when some can think of some Half-Life Source is mentioned.

Not because it was a dissapointment but because it was a horrible port. What I and many people didn't like about the source version was that, when we heard from Valve we were going to get a source remake of Half-life we though it was going to be amazing, although when HL:S was delivered it was just a source port. Although I would absolutely fine with this port if it wasn't for the bugs, glitches and gameplay.

Suprisingly Half-life Source has more bugs than the original game, and these bugs are awful almost breaking the experince. Even after the 10 years its been out, this game hasn't been fixed. Half-Life 1 is my favorite FPS game it topples everything in my opinion(even the sequels), and to be a port how can the gameplay be bad?

Well, since Half-life is running on a new engine the hit points and aiming is horrendous, for example the chopper: In the original game it took one or two hits to know the chopper down and a full charge from the tau cannon. However the the damage never seems to register properly so it makes the game unplayable. And it ruins the shooting with the new kick-backs of the weapons.

Half-Life: Source is an unpolished port and massive trump in valves libary of games.
But would I reccomend it?
Of course not, you should really just grab the original it has the single player campaign working flawlessly and a multiplayer that comes with it, unlike Source where you have to purchase it independently.

But if you feel like playing this game in the source engine and you think it looks good then I would say maybe get it.

Even though there is a source port for the original Half-life that looks superb.

6/10
